questions.text: Two days after delivery, a 4300-g (9-lb 8-oz) male newborn has difficulty feeding and has become increasingly lethargic. His cry has become weak. He was born at term. His mother has a history of intravenous drug use. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 70/48 mm Hg. Examination shows midfacial hypoplasia, diaphoresis, and tremor of the lower extremities. Macroglossia is present. There are folds in the posterior auricular cartilage. The left lower extremity is larger than the right lower extremity. Abdominal examination shows an umbilical hernia. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased tone in all extremities. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcium gluconate is indicated in cases of hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia. In hyperkalemic patients, calcium gluconate is used as a cardioprotective agent that stabilizes the cell membrane of cardiac myocytes to decrease the likelihood of arrhythmia. Patients with hypocalcemia benefit from direct elevation of serum calcium. Although both hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia can cause weakness, the patient's physical examination strongly suggests an underlying genetic condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroxine supplementation is essential for treating congenital hypothyroidism. This patient has some features consistent with hypothyroidism, especially umbilical hernia and macroglossia. However, the presence of other abnormalities, such as hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia, is not consistent with congenital hypothyroidism. Most importantly, deficiency of thyroxine is very unlikely to produce an acute change in health, as seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Administration of hypertonic (3%) saline would be the treatment of choice for severe hyponatremia, which often arises from vomiting or diarrhea without proper volume/sodium replacement. This patient has no history of significant volume loss. Moreover, the presentation of hyponatremia in neonates can be quite variable, with only the most extreme presentations requiring hypertonic (3%) saline. In these cases, patients appear acutely ill and often present with seizures, altered sensorium, and possibly coma. Given the lack of severe neurological dysfunction (e.g., seizure or coma), it is unlikely that this patient is suffering from severe hyponatremia.

D) CORRECT:

The congenital hyperinsulinism associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can cause serious hypoglycemic episodes in neonates. In this patient, poor feeding likely further exacerbated the effects of hyperinsulinemia, ultimately resulting in signs of hypoglycemia such as weak cry, diminished muscle tone, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremor. Normalizing blood sugar levels through prompt administration of glucose should alleviate these abnormalities.

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk of developing nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal tumors; serial screening with abdominal ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein levels is recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin and gentamicin are widely considered first-line agents to treat neonatal sepsis. Certain elements of this patient's presentation could raise suspicion of sepsis, including hypothermia, poor feeding, and lethargy. The presence of other abnormalities (hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia), however, points instead to an underlying genetic syndrome that requires different treatment at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is used to reverse the effects of opioids, most often in cases of overdose. Neonates born to mothers exposed to opioids (either medicinally or recreationally) are at risk of overdose, which manifests with respiratory depression or apnea. This patient is tachypneic, making opioid overdose unlikely.
questions.hint: This newborn has macrosomia, macroglossia, midfacial hypoplasia, hepatomegaly, and hemihypertrophy. These features are suggestive of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text: A 4700-g (10.3-lb) male newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn appears pale. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows midfacial hypoplasia, infraorbital creases, and a large tongue. The right side of the body is larger than the left. Abdominal examination shows that the abdominal viscera protrudes through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus; the viscera are covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows enlarged kidneys bilaterally. In addition to surgical closure of the abdominal wall, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IGF-1 with elevated growth hormone levels is diagnostic of a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can present as gigantism in children. It would be very rare, however, for a newborn to present with a pituitary adenoma, which would also not explain this boy's hemihyperplasia and omphalocele. Serum IGF-1 has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Deregulation of the IGF-2 gene, however, is one of several genes implicated in the development of the syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Low free T4 levels would confirm hypothyroidism, which can be associated with macroglossia and abdominal wall defects (most commonly umbilical hernias). In congenital hypothyroidism, however, a newborn would not be expected to be large for gestational age nor have signs of hemihyperplasia or organomegaly.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels confirm the diagnosis of 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Although patients with 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency can have hypoglycemia during a salt-losing adrenal crisis, other findings would also be expected (e.g., hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia). Furthermore, male neonates with congenital adrenal hyperplasia do not usually have any physical anomalies (i.e., macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, or organomegaly), which are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A growth hormone-producing pituitary adenoma, which can result in organomegaly and a newborn being large for gestational age, can be diagnosed with a cranial MRI. It would be extremely rare, however, for a neonate to present with a pituitary adenoma. Cranial MRI has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is the most likely diagnosis here. A baseline MRI of the abdomen to screen for tumors should be considered and would likely be part of the workup for this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for various tumors, including nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, and neuroblastoma. Abdominal ultrasounds with views of the kidneys are recommended every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for these tumors. Additionally, serum α-fetoprotein levels should also be measured every 2–3 months until 4 years of age to screen for hepatoblastoma. Although measurement of urinary catecholamines has been proposed as a screening method for neuroblastomas, it has not been incorporated into most protocols.

F) INCORRECT:

Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of various genetic disorders, including trisomy 13 and trisomy 18, both of which can be associated with omphalocele. This patient, however, does not have other features of trisomy 13 (e.g., microphthalmia, polydactyly, and congenital heart defects) or trisomy 18 (e.g., prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet). In addition, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by deregulation of imprinting in certain genes, which would not be detected with karyotyping.
questions.hint: This newborn is large for gestational age and presents with facial abnormalities, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, organomegaly, and hypoglycemia. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her tall stature. She is concerned because she is taller than all of her friends. Her birth weight and height were within normal limits. Her father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She is at the 98th percentile for height and 90th percentile for BMI. She has not had her menstrual period yet. Her mother has Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tall stature with broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. Finger perimetry is normal. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 144 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 15 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas cause gigantism in children and adolescents, and acromegaly in adults. Growth hormone (GH) stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn promotes cell proliferation, especially of the bones and cartilage. Excess GH also has a diabetogenic effect, which explains the elevated serum glucose seen in this patient. The treatment of choice for both gigantism and acromegaly is transsphenoidal adenomectomy. Pharmacotherapy with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) is indicated if GH excess is not completely resolved by surgery or if surgery is not possible.

See "Etiology of tall stature" table.

B) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is a medication indicated to treat individuals with McCune-Albright syndrome. One of the findings associated with the condition is precocious puberty, which may lead to accelerated growth and increased height. However, since this patient shows no other features of McCune-Albright syndrome (e.g., cafe-au-lait spots, pathological fractures) and her puberty is delayed rather than precocious, this diagnosis is unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy is the treatment of choice for type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Although this patient presents with fasting hyperglycemia, which is a cardinal feature of diabetes mellitus, she has no other signs or symptoms of the disease, such as polyuria, polydipsia, or weight loss. Her obesity, broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not consistent with T1DM. Moreover, T1DM is commonly associated with stunted growth rather than tall stature.

D) INCORRECT:

Methimazole is indicated for the treatment of Graves disease, a condition that may cause tall stature in adolescents and in which genetic predisposition (e.g., Graves disease in a parent) plays a strong role. Since broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not features of Graves disease and further characteristic features are absent (e.g., tachycardia, diffuse goiter), this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist indicated for the treatment of central precocious puberty. Common features of central precocious puberty include accelerated skeletal growth, early skeletal maturity, early development of secondary sexual features, and early onset of menarche. Because menarche has not yet occurred in this patient, she would be described as having delayed puberty rather than precocious puberty. Since this patient's skeletal maturity is age-appropriate and precocious puberty is unlikely to manifest with isolated accelerated growth, this diagnosis can be ruled out.

F) INCORRECT:

Caloric restriction is the primary measure used to manage overweight and obesity. While excess calorie intake in children may also result in greater height, this patient's broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing should raise suspicion of a different pathology.
questions.hint: Tall stature (> 97th percentile for age and sex), broad hands and feet, prognathism (protrusion of the mandible), and frontal bossing are consistent with the diagnosis of gigantism.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of his tall stature. His father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; his mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. He is at the 99th percentile for height and 88th percentile for BMI. Examination shows pronounced sweat stains below the armpits and broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. His fasting serum glucose is 138 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 16 years. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Tumor of the posterior pituitary gland

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Graves disease is caused by circulating anti-TSH receptor antibodies. Although the condition may cause tall stature in adolescents, it is not associated with hyperglycemia, prognathism, or frontal bossing. Moreover, other characteristic features, e.g., Graves ophthalmopathy, tachycardia, and goiter are absent in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Gigantism is most commonly caused by a benign growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma. Growth hormone (GH) stimulates insulin-like growth factor 1 synthesis in the liver, which in turn promotes cell proliferation, especially of the bones and cartilage. Excess GH also has a diabetogenic effect, which explains the elevated serum glucose in this patient. The treatment of choice for gigantism is transsphenoidal pituitary adenoma resection.

Growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas can cause gigantism in children and adolescents and acromegaly in adults. Both conditions are managed surgically with transsphenoidal adenomectomy, or, if surgery is not possible, pharmacologically with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide).

C) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the posterior pituitary gland can lead to hypersecretion of oxytocin or vasopressin, the two hormones secreted by the posterior pituitary. Neither of these hormones would cause the increase in height, skeletal changes, or hyperglycemia that is seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

McCune-Albright syndrome is caused by mosaic mutations in G-protein signaling. One of the findings associated with the condition is precocious puberty, which may lead to accelerated growth and increased height in adolescence. However, since this patient shows no other features of McCune-Albright syndrome (e.g., cafe-au-lait spots, fibrous dysplasia of bone with pathologic fractures), this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Exogenous anabolic steroid use during adolescence induces premature closure of the epiphyseal growth plates, which leads to stunted growth rather than the linear growth acceleration seen in this patient. Hyperglycemia is, in fact, a common side effect of steroids. However, endocrine symptoms such as gynecomastia or small testes would also be expected with anabolic steroid use. Moreover, anabolic steroids would not cause frontal bossing of the skull or prognathism.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutated growth hormone receptors can be seen in children with idiopathic short stature or dwarfism. However, this patient presents with tall stature and increased linear bone growth.
questions.hint: Tall stature (> 97th percentile for age and sex), excessive sweating, broad hands and feet, frontal bossing, and prognathism (protrusion of the mandible) make gigantism the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl with no significant medical history presents for a routine well-child visit.
Her current height is 146.5 cm (98th percentile for age), and her BMI is at the 50th percentile for age. Review of her growth chart (figure) reveals that her growth velocity has been 5.5 cm per year since her last visit 2 years ago. Her upper-segment to lower-segment ratio is 0.92 (reference range, 0.89–0.95). Her mother’s height is 173 cm, and her father’s is 183 cm.
She has a heart rate of 85 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 100/72 mm Hg. Her development is consistent with with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 1 for pubic hair and 2 for breast development. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s tall stature?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tall stature (defined as height >97th percentile) can be considered familial if a child’s height is concordant with his or her midparental height (expected adult height) and there are no abnormal physical findings or signs of early puberty. Midparental height can be calculated as follows and should be based on direct measurement of both parents, if possible:

Midparental height for boys = (mother’s height + father’s height)/2 + 6.5 cm

Midparental height for girls = (mother’s height + father’s height)/2 - 6.5 cm

If the child’s current height is above the 97th percentile for age and the midparental height falls between the 90th and 99th percentiles, then the child most likely has familial tall stature. In this particular case, the patient’s midparental height is 171.5 cm, which is at the 90th percentile and thus concordant with her current height. Given that she has no early signs of puberty and no abnormal findings on physical examination, she can be assumed to have familial tall stature and does not require additional evaluation.

Key learning point: When a child’s height is above the 97th percentile but consistent with his or her midparental height, and there are no abnormal physical findings or signs of early puberty, the tall stature is most likely familial.

B) INCORRECT:

Precocious puberty should be suspected when a child has early development of sexual characteristics (e.g., breast development in a girl <8 years of age) and early growth acceleration. This patient's development is consistent with sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 2 for breast development and 1 for pubic hair, suggesting that she has reached thelarche at an appropriate age but has not fully begun puberty. In addition, her growth velocity is in the normal range (4.5–6.5 cm/year for girls) and is not consistent with pubertal growth (6–10 cm/year for girls), which would be seen in a girl with precocious puberty.

C) INCORRECT:

Growth-hormone excess, or pituitary gigantism, should be suspected when a patient’s height percentile is 3 to 4 standard deviations above the mean, especially in the absence of a family history of tall stature. Gigantism is rare in children and tends to occur in the presence of a pituitary adenoma; thus, affected patients may present with a rapid increase in growth and crossing of growth percentiles, which this patient does not have. They may also have symptoms related to the pituitary mass, including headaches and visual disturbances. Gigantism is also associated with McCune-Albright syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Marfan syndrome is characterized by tall stature as well as other dysmorphology, including joint subluxation, ligamentous laxity, pectus excavatum, and eunuchoid proportions (reduced upper-to-lower body-segment ratio and an abnormally large arm span). This patient has a normal physical examination and normal body proportions with no report of joint subluxation.

E) INCORRECT:

The specific diagnosis of acromegaly occurs after growth plates have fused and ongoing excess growth hormone causes bone thickening, resulting in coarse facial features, including a triangular nose and a pronounced jaw, and enlarged hands and feet.

questions.text:
You are called to a cesarean delivery, secondary to failure to descend, in a 37-year-old gravida 3, para 2 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation who has had an uncomplicated pregnancy and no significant medical history. A male infant is delivered with clear amniotic fluid and Apgar scores of 8 and 9 at one and five minutes, respectively. He weighs 5 kg.
On physical examination, he appears large and has a protruding large tongue, abdominal distention, and bilateral ear pits. You suspect a genetic syndrome.
Which one of the following characteristics is most likely to be associated with the genetic syndrome suspected in this patient?

choices.text: Increased risk for Escherichia coli infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome often present with hypoglycemia (related to hyperinsulinism), not hyperglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Agenesis of the corpus callosum is not usually seen in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. It is, however, associated with several other syndromes, including Aicardi syndrome, as well as Andermann, Shapiro, acrocallosal, Menkes, and Mowat-Wilson syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no reported increased risk for sepsis in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Children with galactosemia are at increased risk for developing Escherichia coli sepsis.

D) CORRECT:

This newborn has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a growth disorder with a range of features including macroglossia, creases or pits in the ears, visceromegaly, hemihypertrophy, and hypoglycemia. The diagnosis is made on the basis of observed clinical features and, in some cases, genetic testing.

Most individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome have normal chromosome analysis and karyotypes — and no family history of the disease. In 15% of affected individuals, the syndrome is inherited through an autosomal dominant pathway. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome results from defective imprinting of genes controlling growth on chromosome 11p15.5.

Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for developing embryonal tumors such as hepatoblastoma, Wilms tumor, neuroblastoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma. Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome should undergo abdominal ultrasound every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for embryonal tumors. For early detection of hepatoblastoma specifically, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels should be monitored every 2 to 3 months during the first 4 years of life.

Hepatoblastoma is the most common pediatric liver tumor, typically occurring in children younger than 3 years, with a male predominance (2:1). Manifestations can range from an asymptomatic right-upper-quadrant mass to anorexia, weight loss, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis is made through elevated AFP levels and imaging (ultrasound or CT) that reveals a circumscribed, lobular lesion replacing most of the liver. Liver biopsy confirms the diagnosis, and treatment is usually resection followed by chemotherapy.

Key learning point: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of embryonal tumors such as hepatoblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Butterfly vertebrae are usually seen in patients with Alagille syndrome, a multisystem disorder with variable penetrance that is associated with mutations in the JAG1 and NOTCH2 genes. Other features of Alagille syndrome include characteristic facies, bile-duct paucity, chronic cholestasis, and abnormalities in the renal, vascular, skeletal, and ocular systems.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with his mother, who reports he has outgrown his shoes three times in the past year. He has grown 12 cm over 18 months and now measures 190 cm tall. He reports morning headaches that worsen with coughing and difficulty reading the whiteboard from his usual seat. Physical examination shows enlarged hands and feet, coarse facial features, and jaw protrusion. His voice has deepened significantly. Given the clinical presentation, what is the next most appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Oral glucose tolerance test with growth hormone levels
Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although hyperthyroidism can cause tall stature, the specific features of coarse facial characteristics, jaw protrusion, and enlarged extremities are characteristic of growth hormone excess rather than thyroid dysfunction. Thyroid disorders typically present with other systemic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral glucose tolerance test with growth hormone levels is a confirmatory test used after initial screening with IGF-1. This test confirms that growth hormone fails to suppress normally with glucose loading, but it is not the initial diagnostic step.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone age assessment provides information about skeletal maturation and growth potential but does not specifically diagnose the underlying cause of growth hormone excess. While useful in the comprehensive evaluation, it is not the most appropriate initial test for the suspected condition.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Serum IGF-1 is the most appropriate initial biochemical test for suspected pituitary gigantism. The clinical presentation of rapid growth with coarse facial features, jaw protrusion, enlarged extremities, and mass effect symptoms strongly suggests growth hormone excess. IGF-1 levels directly reflect growth hormone activity and serve as the recommended initial screening test before proceeding to more specific confirmatory tests.

E) INCORRECT:

While MRI of the pituitary would eventually be necessary to identify a pituitary adenoma, biochemical confirmation of growth hormone excess should be obtained first. MRI is typically performed after establishing the diagnosis through laboratory testing.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after colliding with a parked car at low-speed while riding his bicycle. He reports that he didn't see it. He was wearing a helmet, did not hit his head, he has sustained no visible injuries, and has no pain. Over the past few months, he has experienced intermittent headaches. His parents have noticed rapid growth over the last year, and he has outgrown multiple pairs of shoes. Vital signs are normal. His height is 193 cm (6 ft 4 in). Visual field testing reveals loss of peripheral vision bilaterally. Neurologic examination is otherwise normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate appropriate imaging for this patient?

choices.text: Hand and wrist X-rays to determine bone age
CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has no concerning features for intracranial trauma that merits an urgent noncontrast CT. Noncontrast CT is insensitive for pituitary and parasellar pathology and may miss the diagnosis entirely.

B) CORRECT:

Correct — This adolescent’s tall stature, coarse facial features, and bitemporal hemianopia are classic for a growth hormone–secreting pituitary macroadenoma compressing the optic chiasm. MRI with sellar cuts is the imaging modality of choice. Baseline endocrine studies (GH, IGF-1, prolactin, cortisol, TSH) and urgent endocrinology/neurosurgery consultation are also indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone-age films assess skeletal maturity in children with growth disorders but are irrelevant to the acute evaluation of visual loss and suspected intracranial mass. The ED priority is neuroimaging to identify possible pituitary macroadenoma, not estimation of growth potential.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography evaluates vascular pathology but poorly visualizes the sella turcica and optic chiasm. The presentation lacks focal deficits or subarachnoid features suggesting a vascular cause.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the orbits identifies optic neuritis or local compressive lesions, not chiasmal compression. The pattern of bitemporal hemianopia indicates a sellar mass, best evaluated with a pituitary protocol MRI.
